I need to say this again.
Hi, I'm Marco Tabellini

I'm an assistant professor
at Harvard Business School.
I am a political economist

who works on the economic, social,
and political effects of immigration.

I started initially
by looking at how the arrival of European

immigrants in the early 20th century
influenced the US economy.

And then gradually my research
has evolved, focusing more and more on
how immigrant waves change
the social and cultural landscape.
What fascinates me about immigration

is that it has, of course, economic
effects because immigrants are workers,

but also has important social
and cultural consequences.

They can affect
not just the local economy, but also,

and I think importantly, the society
and the social norms,

as well as the institutions,
of the receiving countries.

We live in a world which
is getting increasingly interconnected.

People are, moving across the world
in larger and larger numbers,

partly because of weather shocks
that displace people or conflict

but also because technological changes
make it easier for people to migrate.

Understanding what are the social,
economic, and cultural implications
of this phenomenon will be important.

Recently I started working on what I hope
will become a new agenda of mine

at the intersection
between climate and migration.

We test the idea of whether immigrants
mention climate,

namely whether they seek out destinations
with climate
that aligns with that of their origin.

And, if this is true, it can have important
implications
for our predictions and for understanding

how climate change will affect
migration patterns across the world.

My first case was about an immigration
reform that US
Congress tried to pass in 2013.
Despite bipartisan support
the reform was actually not successful.
It failed.

And so in the classroom, we
tried to understand why
this was the case.
So today

I brought, the picture
of the sailing boat

that I used to sail on when I was in Italy,
before coming to the United States.

Sailing is an important 
component of my life.
If I didn't become a professor

I would have really liked
to become a professional sailor.
The sailing experience of my life
is that it's how I met my wife.
